newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium okays mutual funds for unlisted stocks.
newsitem.headline: Belgium okays mutual funds for unlisted stocks.

text.p: The Belgian government approved on Friday a draft law establishing mutual funds which will invest in unlisted growth companies.

"The new funds...will allow an indirect investment in growth companies. The fund will be bourse-listed, not the companies in its portfolio. This way, it is possible to create a liquid market for companies which by themselves are not ready for a bourse listing," the government said in a statement.
Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene told a news conference the new funds, to be called Pricafs/Privaks, are part of a package of measures aimed at stimulating risk capital.

The statement gave no details of the law, but Belgian Finance Minister Philippe Maystadt said in March 1996 that the funds would have to hold at least 50 percent of their assets in shares. He also said they would be banned from holding more than 20 percent of their assets in shares or bonds issued by just one company.
